posts.name: Cameron (Advanced Programmer)
posts.cooked: Working with the Arducam ov9281 and ov9782, I found the goofy USB JST and USB A connector to be finicky. I created a circuit board to solder directly to the front of the camera to convert it to USB C. I’m trying to gauge if people would be interested in preordering or ordering this. I was thinking about offering a pre-soldered kit with the camera and just the circuit board. The solder connections are fairly small. I also created a case to be used with a locking USB C cable. I am still working on ideas and looking for recommendations for mounting.

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked: What we have normally done is get a new USB extension cable and cut off the socket end so we can strip and solder the 4 USB wires directly to the front of the camera. This has been much more reliable for us than the connector on the back and the included cable.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Would definitely be interested in this.
We’d buy a few. The latching connector for the USB C is a nice touch.

posts.name: MetabolicCloth
posts.cooked: I have another idea: using the 5V regulator from my existing circuit to provide a separate 5V supply for the microcontroller unit. This could potentially reduce the need for expensive and hard-to-source components like the LM7805CPV.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: So thrifty now has a screw-locking USB-C cable, which might be suitable for enhancing a camera case rather than the circuit board.

posts.name: Cameron (Advanced Programmer)
posts.cooked: I needed a reliable USB-C cable that teams could buy, but it appears that Thrift only offers locking USB-C to USB-C cables right now.

posts.name: Cameron (Advanced Programmer)
posts.cooked: The boards would come with the USB-C connector pre-soldered. Teams would only have to solder the four USB pins and the reinforcement joints.

posts.name: Cameron (Advanced Programmer)
posts.cooked: Pre-assembled cameras would also include wired ribbon cables if the camera features them, such as the ov9281 model, with acrylic conformal-coated boards assembled into the unit.

posts.name: MetabolicCloth
posts.cooked: Fantastic! That’s what I expected. Very excited about using these on our cameras, the JST are not rugged enough for high schoolers.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: I really like this design! I definitely feel like there’s a use for having it secured well inside of a case too. Redux also sells a locking C to C cable, though it’ll be out of stock for a few more days. We also have a locking case design that uses it with the Zinc-V for power. I did order some locking A to C, but the screws tend to get in the way of other ports on coprocessors, so we haven’t made it available for sale right now. In general, I’m a lot more worried about the fragile cables on the camera side than the large USB A that plugs into the coprocessor.

posts.name: Cameron (Advanced Programmer)
posts.cooked: I have ordered 250 PCBs that should be delivered in the next couple of weeks. I'm still working on the case design and planning to test out some ESD-safe 3D printed cases. For testing, I used this USB-C cable from Amazon.

posts.name: Cameron (Advanced Programmer)
posts.cooked: I have the boards available for sale now on etsy. I will be adding a video on how to solder it and a CAD model for the case. Currently, it's not very feasible to sell the entire camera assembly as I originally intended.

posts.name: Cameron (Advanced Programmer)
posts.cooked: I posted the case to Printables to download the Arducam OV9281 OV2311 Case from JuneMunk's website. I printed it with support for the mounting tabs using the large flat face down. The mounting holes are 2.25 inches apart and designed for 10-32 bolts.

link_counts.title: Arducam OV9281 OV2311 Case by Juniormunk | Download free STL model | Printables.com

posts.name: Jai Gupta
posts.cooked: Please provide the PCB Gerber files.

posts.name: Cameron (Advanced Programmer)
posts.cooked: I just updated the shipping cost for this. For some reason, the settings I had set caused Etsy to charge an astronomical price for shipping. https://www.etsy.com/listing/1842851233/arducam-ov9281ov9782-usb-c-converter-pcb

posts.name: Cameron (Advanced Programmer)
posts.cooked: I have updated the cost and packaging of these products, so instead of buying them individually, you get a 5-pack for $14.99. I noticed many teams were only purchasing one or two, which I don’t recommend. I suggest having backups if you plan to use them on your robot. These boards were used during the season, but we faced an issue with soldering connections.
